title: Here’s what the map of the world actually looks like
text:
The map shows the correct smaller surface area of predominantly white countries which were previously exaggerated (Picture: Creative Commons) Pretty different to how you imaginedâ€Ś right? 
The map, introduced by public schools in Boston this week, changed studentsâ€™ views of the world instantly.
Nude images and sex tape of WWE star Paige stolen and leaked online While Europe and the United States appear smaller than on the Mercator projection map weâ€™re used to seeing in school geography classes, city authorities believe this updated map â€“ the Gall-Peters projection â€“ show countries in their correct proportions.
The well-known map exaggerated the size of the imperialist powers and highlighted colonial trade routes.
The Mercator Projection, created by Flemish cartographer Gerardus Mercator in 1569, shows the northern hemisphere enlarged in size with North America and Europe larger than South America and Africa.
The Mercator projection (Picture: Getty) Mercator also shifted the equator, meaning Germany appears in the middle of the map and not in a truer more northern position.
Teen ditches prosthetic leg after a decade of hiding her disability Students in Boston are now studying the Peters-Gall projection, a map that shows a more realistic vision of the world by cutting the US, UK and Europe in size to reflect their actual surface area reports the Guardian .
The newer map was published by Arno Peters, a German historian, in 1974. His projections matched up to 19th-century mapmaker James Gall.
By highlighting the inaccuracies of the Mercator Projection, and showing pupils the Peters-Gall Projection instead, Boston schools are starting a â€˜three-year effort to decolonize the curriculum in our public schoolsâ€™, according to Colin Rose, assistant superintendent of opportunity and achievement gaps for Boston public schools.
Around 86% of Bostonâ€™s 57,000 students are non-white. Rose added that teaching authorities in the district are aiming to take a look at other subjects to shift the presentation on white history as dominant over other perspectives.
